interpretation.p: All digital surrogates of the original source are linked with the markup textfile.
All Gaelic (and English) texts have an English summary, index terms, keywords, and, where applicable, a taxonomic reference.
For some Gaelic (and English) texts a bibliographic reference(s) will be provided to other sources.

correction.p: Errors from the original source transcription have been kept to a minimum by employing stringent quality control procedures. In addition, all texts have been proof‐read by the text editors.

A guiding principle of the Alexander Carmichael notebooks markup procedure is to approximate the original document as closely as possible, so that the character of Carmichael's transcriptions is preserved along with its content. XML (eXtensible Markup Language), with its capacity to convey emendations such as deletions (crossed out) and supralinear additions and so forth, can digitally reproduce an authentic version which reflects the source documents.
Where authorial changes, e.g. substitution, have occurred in the text then this has been annotated.
Where there are errors they have been corrected and words which were difficulty to decipher has been indicated

In such cases missing words or letters have been supplied. Quotation marks and other missing grammatical marks have in the main not been supplied. Where there are gaps in the text usually because the word was inaudible (some background noise, perhaps) or where the transcriber could not make out what was being said in the act of transcription (perhaps the speaker was inarticulate or mumbling or for whatever reason) then these have been tagged, though not explained; where a word is now difficult, illegible or just unclear, then this has also been tagged.
All such changes have been annotated in accordance with TEI 5 procedures.

normalization.p: No normalization of the words such as changing the source text to conform with current Gaelic orthographic conventions has been undertaken. The texts are as given with only minor editorial changes. in order to preserve the integrity of the original texts.

quotation.p: All opening quotation marks, hyphens, dashes, apostrophes, periods, colons, etc. have been retained in the source text and have been encoded in accodance with ISO entity references, etc.
All double marks have been processed using straight quotation marks, that is, ". All single quotation marks have been rendered using apostrophe.

hyphenation.p: End‐of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.

segmentation.p: Folio numbers have been added in pencil at the top of each notebook page are retained using the pb (pagebreak) element together with the n attribute for the page number and the ed attribute to specify the edition.
When an tale‐text or song which, more often than not, fills more than one page, it is segmented with page break.

langUsage.language: Approximately 40% of the fieldnote and transcription bokos are Scottish Gaelic, and the remaining 60% consist of English or Scots, along with stray quotations in Latin.

div.p:
Friday 2 Sep.September 1870 from Oban to Lis
more. Mr Duncan Carmichael
in the boat who told me Calumcille
Maoluag and Ordhean were brothers
M.Maoluag & CCalumcille were making for Lismore
& each trytrying who shldshould be ashore first MMaoluag
put his finger on the who thart thart tobht on the tottobhta & cut it off and when near
shore threw it ashore saysaying Tha m
fhuil us m fheoil eir tir agus
s lioms an t eilean & then MaolMaoluag got Lismore
& Cal.Calumcille went to Iona (Ithona).

Lismore got its name from having
been a garden for Macdonald of the Isles,
who had taitaigh eir leleth Alaba (Baile's leleth Alaba?)
All the sur.surrounding country was then a wilderness.
Orran was bur.buried alive & on the 4 day
CokillColmkille openopened his grave to see if he was still
alive – which he was. CalCalumchille asked him
how he felt during his three dysdays in the
grave. Oran repreplied that IfrinIfrinn was not so
bad as aledgalledged whereupon CalCalumcille said Uir eir
eir suil Odhrain mun lauirlabhuir e tuille
coraircobhraidh when the earth was shovelled back
upon him again ColColmkille fearfeared that such
lang.language comgcoming frfrom OrOran might injure the comcompassion
he had at heart.

At Eala was round a mound like dikedyke
a vryvery charnel of bones which were buridburied there.
Pins & brooches and a silver spoon got there.
Nunnery is said to have stood close by & the
Eala was where the people used to retreat for
a day & a year after which they came out white-
washed. On Creagan-nam-baintearnaCreagan-nam-bainteaghrna is Tobar
nam baintigbaintighearna where the nuns are said to come to

of the manse.

An Gorm mor livlived at Ach an duin. He

He took with him at Camus a ghuirm
at Eigneig. A bull made his apappearance & the other
ran off. When his frndsfriends camcame they fodfound the gorm
killed & took him. Leac-a-Ghuirm is on the Crois.

The MacLachlans of Fiart took the lady
off the Lady's rock & brotbrought her to LismorLismore & then
sent her to the main land. Dr MacLach.MacLauchlan
EdinEdinburgh is descddescended from these MacLachlans.

The yew tree at Bearnary sheltsheltered 1000 men or
12 boats. None of the propri.proprietors has came to the propproperty
father to son.

The MacLeans of Duart stole the heir
of Dunstaffnage & brotbrought him to Aoine Mor
na h-aird. ThyThey had him chained there. One
MacGilleDhuiMacGilleDhuibh of Lismore threw some
arrows & killed the keeper of yngyoung Campbell
ten & three or 4 others. The Lismore people
hurrhurried off with the yngyoung heir & ere the Mac
leans got a boat they only came up to
the LisLismore people at Killchearan The
2 peoppeople turndturned upon each other & all the DDuart people
were killed & buried in the nearest isle to
KilchiarKilchiaran – ElanEilean na braich where their
graves are still pointpointed out with stones
at each end.

The last bishop of Lismore was brotbrought frfrom Ach
nan duin to Dundee a prisprisoner from which
he nevnever retreturned. This was the last bishbishop of Lismore.

base of wuponwhereupon & which banns are

is of a soft kind & not native
laity in mainland
of the cross in the church

below this when it fell down back when

Tobar a bhaiste close to church where
The Clach. chuchurch was built by the Papists but
not roofed. The Prot.Protestants roofed. This wldwould leave

The remremains of a buildgbuilding behibehind the churchurch was a

on Druim na bithe. The crofter had

The 2 pieces of the coftcoftcroft were separseparate & the croftcrofter

croft & when the ministminister saw this he took

Aulay who did this a strong head m
much disliked here. Mr Stewart padpaid 2/6

Mr Cheyne came into who told him

for InvrInveraray he stood up in the churchurch the

to the relief of the people. He it was
who put the brangas up to the churchurch wherwhere

neck for a night & a daday. Others durgduring the

Aulay was a duinduine borb borb. They

Two were going to be mar.married but he was
against it. The two got marmarried & said

div.p:
Druim na bithe was the plplace where the
malefactmalefactors used to be colcollected for the parparochial court. When
their sentsentence was brotbrought out they were brotbrought to Croc
na croiche where a croich was alwysalways fixtfixed
& here he was hanged. Croc na croiche was
is on the ssouth side of the dikedyke betbetween the smiths
croit & Lag nan cailleach on the TaiTaigh
chlachain farm.

Eaglais Mhaoluag stood near the
Borstair na croise on top of the crois.
When digdigging graves the foundfoundations of this churchurch
are soon come upon & the lime & pieces
of pottery ared dug up. This churchurch took
fire when full of people when all were
burnt up. The whole debris of bones
& stones were dumdumped down about the
Eala. The Eala was a diodan for
malefactmalefactors.. Here a nunynunnery stood &c.

John Roy saw a perfect charnel
of bones here. Free stone lime & stones
are fdfound in new graves in the Crois SSouth
of the Eala – 12 yrdyards – got the stone over.
RevMacgregor Didnot seem to have
been plplaced over any partparticular person Only
a heap of disordisordered bones scatscattered under
it like any of the SurSorrounding land. Nearby
20 feet NNorth of the Eala was fdfound a large fine
stone unsculpdunsculpted stone with a few
skeltskeletons under it of imimmense size. The stone
was taken away & placed in the manse
byre door where it remremains still.

SSouth of the Eala near the Manse
well was a small buryburying plplace 12x12 yrdsyards
with a wall round it where all the un
baptised childchildren were burdburied. John
Roys fathfather in law told him that he
saw the child of Duncan Mac
Ille chonail Bailenango'anBailenangobhain burburied
here. He was the last perperson 100 yrsyears ago.
The dikedyke removremoved when the Lon IocarIocair
a chlachain was drained. Deer
horns & querns – one of the querns fndfound
below the Eala at the little gate
the other was in 2 halfshalves found in Iocar
a chlachchlachain. A small ladle of copper
like a tobacctobacco pipe copper pins with the
* on top. also some small stones like
a pencil with a cross on top. Also
stone images. None kept.
Children used to take hold of each others
hands & plplaced another on the arms and say

div.p:
Skulls found on larach Taichlach
air & Skeletons.

Campbell of {Airds {Stewart of Appin was hanged over the wall of Duart Castle by Maclean. The Baron
of Bachuil & his two datsdaughters went away witwith
a boat to Duart. When they reareached the Baron broke
a hole throthrough all the boats he could get so as to preprevent
pursuit. He then cut down the body of his chief
& he & his dautsdaughters carrdcarried it to their boat & started home.
They saw a large black boat purpusuing & when near the
Mousdale When the purpursuers' boat was close upon
the purs.pursuit the latter swerved round & ran
throthrough the creek dividividing Mousdale. The othother later
folfollowed but stuck in the narrow & the other got
away & came to Port Chailleach at
where the corpese was
land.landed & bur.buried in the sand till the Baron got
men with him brotbrought it to the churchurch at Clach
an. Campbell of AirdsStewart of Appin was burburied at the
EEast end near the wall. A sculptsculpured stone is
over CampbellStewart & when the church was
floored word was sent to the Baron of
Bachuil of the day a descddescendant of the
Baron who took the body frfrom Duart &
asking if the stone would be thrown out
& he sugsuggested that it should be sunk
which was done to the level of the flags.

An Gorm Mor was the last who lived at
Castle Achnanduin. He took a boat
& crew & went to the Gaireleass.When
he landed he requestrequested the peoppeople to leave.
When they went out out they saw
a raging black bull tearing down the glen & he & the Gorm Mor
meet 40 yrsyards from the shore where
they fotfought. When thythey went back thythey
fdfound the Gorm Mor dead & brotbrought him
to the Crois where he is buried in the
plodplot of the Livingstones near
the Barons of Bachuil. He was the Gorm Mor Mac an Leigh.
This stone has not been touched for at
least 200 yrsyears.

Caman na Bachuil grew
on the angle of the EEast of the Crois. It
grew in one night. The BarBaran saw a visvision
which told him that a caman grew
that night on the Crois & to come
& cut it. He came & cut it & it was
so wonderful that peopeople flocked
to see it. It was then brotbrought to the Pope who
got it gilt with gold & gave it to the
Baron as a symbol of office.
None knew what wood this was.
This Caman formed part of the oiroighreachd
of Bachuil & is now in EdinEdinburgh Argyll Duke of
Crois dudubh Lismoir is a black slate peeling off in scales.
The Baron of Bachuil was once at
shinty in Airds & forgot his caman. When he
got home he remrembered his loss & returned
in search. When put out the boat in Port
nam marbh the caman came there
turngturning about his feet & nearnearly knocked
him down. The third time he stoopstopped & pullpulled
it up & found this which was abtabout his feet to be
his caman.

MaideanMaighdean a Chaisteil lived in Chaisteal
Chaifein. She wore a green dress & walked
about. Would this have been Beoil ni'eannighean
RiRigh Lochlan? Another haunted Dun alla
who used to roll down mulachagan upon
the servants when they displdispleased her. She was
a nic Iachain Nic-I-achain

ImmImmense human bones were dug from the
foundfoundations of this SSaint Maoluag ruins when
the dyke was built round the buryburying plplace
a few yrsyears ago.

div.p:
Nic Gillemhicheil haunted the
Loch Glenfaochan family. She had 2 tola
main betbetween which she walked to & fro
and wailed before the death of one of the
family so when her voice was heaheard
twas said O its only NicGillemhNicGillemhicheil bhocbhochd.
Dearnagan = a handhandsel (bannock?)

The candlestick fdfound on the Crois stood
on three was a triangle representing the Trin
ity at base & top. The base was like a saucer
candlestick of fine gold & abtabout 8 in high got
abtabout 40 yrsyears ago in digdigging the grave of a datdaughter of NiNighean Mac
Coll RugarbhRhugarbh Benderloch.

The Lord of the Isles visitvisited Castle Gordon & called
at the door. The Duchess appappeared & spoke sharply
to him for calling in the Dukes absence. He bade
her goodbye & to tell her husb.husband that Alastair RuaRuadh
buachaille nan Eileanan had called. WhnWhen
the Duke retreturned she told him that such a person
called. The Duke asked what she said to him she told him
that she scoldscolded him away
from the door. The Duke startdstarted imimmediately after
his Lordship & brotbrought him back in his care
to the Duches.Duchess's confusion.

The Glaisgirig used to haunt Allt aog
ain.

Eowan buidhe na h-uamh – Uamh EownEowan
bhuibhuidhe in Eigineig – & his wife used to come to
LisLismore to steal sheep. They took their boat at night &
return ere daylight. At the base of a cliff at Allt
aogain there is a narrow path below
which there is a stream. He used to lie
in a nook here & the wife drove the sheep past
him. There was one strong black sheep which
he was anx.anxious to catch but was defeat.defeated. So he wldwould
call out Tharam fhastfhathast caora dhudhubh mo
ghoistighoistidh!

There are peoppeople living who saw the ruin
of Lon na straioc down to TaiTaigh phuill in
stead of now down Allt aogain.

The Gorm Mors datdaughter went to church at ClachClachan
& in retgreturning home to Achananduin died at Laig
uanach from a plaigh then ravginravaging LisLismore. She
was bur.buried where she fell.

Tis said one MacGlaisein was the last
in Achnanduin Castle.

Cladh-a ghleannain and Pille bhride AchnanAchnanduin
17 perpersons were killdkilled in the Castle one day. Clach
uin nam-baintearnannam-baintighearna. Chābag was a
round stone abtabout the buaile which taken
away & which caused mischance to those
who took it. An Caibeal Lag a chaibilchaibeil.

A man plow.ploughing in the isle of Bearnaray was cursgcursing
when he & his pair of horses were swalledswallowed up by the
opening of the earth. The hole is pointed out still.
Carn at end of Teampall.

Phrēnphort the quarry where the stones
of the castle. The smithy is close by at Beal
ach & PeinPeighinn feannaig.

the MacanLeigh Mor lived in the isle
& his datdaughter came to see her muime & oide who
lived at Laguanach where Eown Car
michael is who were in the PlaiPlaigh. Her fath-father
came aftafter her & stood at the dorlin & calcalled
her back & told her he woldwouldshoot her she
died of the plaiplaigh & was burdburied at a grey boulder
at Pillebhride. MacCeallaich was the last
bishop at Achnandun. All the stones
for the castle must have been hoisted.

Croc sneacaig is a carn iobairt on top
of a hill in Fiart close by is a cist & anothanother
is on top of Achananard.

Clach na Cabaig was at Temple in the isle
& althoalthough all the calves in the isle sucked their
dames the banachsbanachags would not know it at
night on the quantity of milk. If it ever
taken over to the baile at nitnight it was saisaid
to be fdfound in its plplace in the moringmorning. It was stolen
away by an Irish man who anchored
close by. The grandfathgranfather of the present
Macdugal of Dun olla had a stonstone
calcalled the Leigh. This used to be carcarried abtabout for
cures for the water over it. Colin CampbCampbell's
wifes mother got it fr.from MacDMacDougall & he reqtrequested
her to take partparticular care of it or else it wdwould
leave her.

Alast.Alastair MacColla was told that as
long & no longer he would seachainn Eag
lais Lismore & MuilMuileann ghocam go
or MuilMuileann Charnasarig he wldwould prospprosper.
He burnt the two & hence he came to
grief. The church at ClachClachan was
100 yrsyears without a roof.

TaiTaigh Laguanach TaiTaigh Bheolain at
Larach taitaigh BheolBheolain NNorth of Allt aogaogain & TaiTaigh

Cruban Dunan us Baidein
was 3 brobrothers who came fr.from Ceannloch & were the fistfirst
who came to inhabtinhabit Lismore. Cruban built
Dun Chrubain Dunan on Druim an
Dunain. DunDunan & Baidein were
togtogether build D-Druim an DunDunain but quarquarelled & BaidBaidein
left & went to BenBenderloch to Salen sligneachsligeanach(?)
& built a town for himself to show his brobrother
that he was in seilbh fearain. This he calcalled Dun
Bhaidein. When he went to the top of the
hill he call Druim ard now Aird mhun
rais now the modern town of Croc sgur- ain

Killemhoire was of old calcalled now Fiart
& Runa fiart. The Kill is close to the mill stream
N.North side abtabout 30 ydsyards frfrom stream in the angle bet.between
the road to the mill & the road to Fiart. The
Killemhoire march is at Sron na fuaracfuartachd
at the sea. The Kil for Killechiarain was whewhere
DonlDomhnall an Dannsair's house. This old man
John Black 86 yrsyears saw leaca lì graves stones in both
these Kills. The peoppeople used as divdivisions betbetween their cows
again!

JonJohn Bl.Black says the Castle of Achnan
duin was built abtabout 1209. He saw this in a book
the bishops of Kilchiarain had Latin one papage
& EngliEnglish on tthe other. Lithi-sgeirLiath-sgeir.

At Dun chruban was got a bone ring
thick as a finger 3 ininches diadiameter a sword head
lots of teeth of wild beasts vryvery long. JonJohn Black
& his brobrother cleaned out the rubbish & pput a 9 fire
place on the inside with polipolished peltills
sursurrounding each equally poitpointing off.

TaiTaigh seilg Croc Bheolain
Clach lialiath in placplace of that name & frfrom which
the plplace is namenamed. And in Fiart at Port
Bheathain near Muisdal calcalled ClaClach
Bheathain. DulDughall RuaRuadh Neacail ul whnwhen
mad reareached this stone & ststood on the top. Clach
an trinistrithinis in Aoine Achanis

Tobar Port us Muillean Killmhoir close by the Killmhoire
MacLachlain na Fiart whose houshouse
was at Achadhun & which this man took
down the clachaclachan steisteidh & then threw down
Creag nan eun to clear the pl.place. He also
clearcleared the steisteidh of taitaigh biorlin Mhic
Lachlain & walked undunder the shadow
of the craouncraobhan leamhain formgforming straid
MhicLachMhicLachain 50 yrdsyards long x 12 feet the trees closed
atop. The sraid was in the midst of
a wood. The MacLachMacLachlain inhabinhabited Fiart
for tri linnean till they sold it to MacAonaisMacAonghais
Dhunstainis & who sold again to Combie.
MacLachMacLachlain was walkgwalking throthrough his propproperty onone
dyday when an old woman met him & said
Run mo chridhe ort a MhicLMhicLachlain
Run do chridhe eir a chloich ghlas
ud thall a bhean pointgpointgpointing to a stone pillpillar
& the split down frfrom top to bottom. She
was a witch. The side which fell of the obel
isk was rolrolled down & made stair Chill
a mhoir of it where it still is. This
was the first stair in this part of the
Highlands. In TaiTaigh na Fiart was
where the coraichean na duchaduthcha
gan socrachadh. MacLachMacLachlain gave
the womwoman put his hand in his
pocket 2/6 gave this to the geasaiche.

The door of the church on top of the
Crois was in the west.

Dun Fraoin is so calcalled from Fraon
one of the Feinne.

Gill odhar is now broken &c. This
was the only plplace where there was an echo.
In seomar GilloarGillodhar was where the arms
were kept. John Bl.Black fondfound two irons like ploplough
socks with a feather on eaeach side & as big
(Arrow heads?) in makgmaking a drain in Aoine Port an daimh in A.duinAchanduin.

The caman is said to have been sculpsculpted on
a gravestone on the spot allgedalleged to have grown the Caman.

On his deathbed DonlDomhnall dudubh tiarntighearna sent for
the Baron & now & then he would ask for him but his
wife never sent the message. He used to preach in
the agsages of episcopy.

From the Eala to the smithy a gravel
walk & on each side a bog. In a circuit below
stakes like a plowghshareploughshare fixtfixet in the
ground at intervals.

Skewers (dealga fionntrain) & stone needles
& many things were found in IocarIochdar
a chlachain when draining it.

(1) Porthole facgfacing Glensanda. Near the outside are holes in wall as
if for large bars abtabout 8x8 in. PinaclePinnacle on SSouth abtabout 2 of high inside & at
the other 3 or 4 much the same. SSouth pinpinnacle a slope in wall
at top of which is a circle eir a stand.
Larach TaiTaigh nam fiann 40 ydsyards diamdiamter.

One solitary plane tree near TaiTaigh mor Phort
charrain.

From InverayInverary & all sur.surrounding countycountry came to buybury
in Lismore Dun fraoin (Cul fraoin =
Cultaic) was a buryburying place. Full of stones
& bones. Cheyne carted 2 carts of bones fr.from Uamh
Dhun fraoin to the R.Roman C.Catholic bgburying pl.place which gave grtgreat
offoffence to RRoman CCatholics. Tor-an-aolaichTorr-an-aolaich a bgburying plplace this N.North end
Achnacrois.

GilleaspaGilleasbaig Caimbeul was rented the whole
of Fiart His bro.brother was a CollCollector of Customs Green
ock. His othother brobrother was his baillie at Fiart be
fore coming to BalnangoanBailnangobhainn whose son
bcambecame the DualoulDomhnull dudubh Rois & Mr DulDughall Kil-
more.
Crois dudubh 29 x 16 x 2.

Cilleachain the "caibeil" & leacan cinn are still
seen on the Eirebal mor. There are 3 Eirebals Mor
beag us E-Eirebal an fhaing. Aoine full of wood.
This & Alasra were the two last places to retain wood.

div.p:
Eala below the road at IocarIochdar a
chlachain. Here criminals came
& if they got their hand of on this stone.

Below the entrance to Castle Chaifin was
some large building some 40 yyards x 10
Comraich na h-eaglais in Lismore

LigheLiath sgeir on a line between Musdail
and Bearnaray from which the grave
stones of Iona were taken. The marks of the
quarrying tools are still visible. The rock is
seen at half tide. The rock is opopposite Cailleach
Campber is a place in Lismore. Where?

div.p:
Sithein a Phiobaire Kil Pheadair
SSouth Uist. Used to hear pippiping therthere.
ClanClann an t Saoir Smearcleit werwere clebrcelebrated
pippipers a mach s a staigh cha
rorobh ann a gheogheobhadh buaibuaidh orra. One
son was a "lecheallachlethchiallach" unfit for a pippiper
So he was sent to faire buaile cruicruidh
He saw the sithsithein light & he ent.entered. First
placgplacing a knife or nail in the door
aftafter which the Sith.Sithein could close it.

"Rath us ealain rath us eal.ealain" said he
& all the sithsithein pippipers. Rath gun ealealain rath
gun ealealain they rep.repeated & tried to close the door
& keep him but they coudcould not so they
were oblgobliged to give him also the ealealain Go you
homhome said the sean.seann bod.bhodach sīsīth & send
the bones of the black dead horse
at yryour fathfather's door & get a pipe made
& you shall be a pip.piper such as nonnone
of yryour people nevnever saw. He did & got a pipe & settsettled
to piob.piobaireachd & eclipeclipsed them all. We may stop
if you rerefrain said his fathfather and brobrother for no one
will listlisten toto you so go you to out into
the world and not mnmentionus. He did so
thethere was. celebr.celebration. Get the story of the one
who got the bannock frfrom the bean
choal chotchota uaine

Two were paspassing a sisithein & headheard maist
readh with.within glug us glag. They
were ploughploughing near the SithSithein. I wish
I had a drink of what she is maistmaistreadh
to caisg mo iotaiotadh. Thainig bean
chaol chota uainuaine mach agus
deoch aicaice ann an corn. & she
offoffered it to him & he refused it.

Fhir a shìn mo dheoch s nach
do ghaghabh mo dheoch galar na te chuir
a chir Chiad-aoine na ceann
orstort. She then ofoffered it to the other & he took it
Fhir a ghaghabh mo dheoch 's nach do dh iarr
mo dheoch rath us buaibuaidh gam bi eir
a cheann.

Se eir ruaruadh Chroca breaca Staonabrig
a womwoman left to go to SieinSithein Buail Iarrais
braibraigh StaongStaonabrig. She went to her friends &
took away the coire. The old man
withwithin said A bhean bhalbh sin sa
bhean bhalbh thaingthainig thus a tir nan
marbh a rug eir a choire na
crutha fuasgail an deigh 's ligleig
an dearg. Tir nam marbh
Cillemhicheil at Ormacleit
Crois bhroca brea.breaca still stands
down near the mol. near the sisithein
An Dun Ceardach on Geirinish
machair.

Cairiste means 6 days in harvest & 6 in
spring which the pe evryevery smoke in the
country had to send a perperson to the proprietor
or his factor in lieu & at any other time
when wanted. All "the little ten" had this.

MacUistean GhrinishGhriminish NNorth Uist had
a sealladh. He had datdaughter of Boisdale marmarried
He had a cairiste & he went out
to see how they were get on at shearing.
In pas.passing sith.sithean mor GhrinishGhriminish he
hadheard ranaich cloinne & briagair
mna'anmnathan & headheard a sisithean saysaying Uiste
sibh gus an suidheachea clar
mor Mhic Uist.Uistean s gheogheobh sibh
an leoir. He turnturned home & the bean
fuine set to bake the food for the cairiste
She filfilled the clar & being so fulfull bits of dough
were falfalling ovrover it. She was going to take thmthem
up but Mac UistUistean stamped his foot
at her so the si.sithein seen by him but un
seen by her were comgcoming to pick up
the bits. He then went past the sisithein
& there was ceol us aighear within.
While standgstanding looklooking at the shean
he saw the sith coming with a
cridheal mor bodaich & plagplacing
it in a clais & takgtaking a child left therthere
by the a woman who had sickly hushusband
& who had to come herself. The cridheal
bod.bodaich began crying. The child she
ran to take up the child. Mac UistUistean
stampstamped his foot at her & woudwould not
allow her. In course of time the sith.sithein
seeing the cridheal bodbodaich breakbreaking his heatheart
crycrying came & repl.replaced the right baby & took
up the bodach. Mac UistUistean forbadforbade any
woman again to take a baby to the harvtharvest
field & to stay at home if she could
not come otherwise.

div.p:
Alex.Alexander Ma brother to Flora Macdonald shot
in CarrasyCarrasay. Was on a vistvisit to his Aunt Isebal
nieannighean fir AiriAiridh mhuilmhuilean. Saw a flock of ducks
in the Creagun below the house. He rushrushed
to the gun not knowknowing it was loadloaded It went
off & kilkilled him. Old DonDonald who was thnthen
2 yrsyears saw the blood. He was sent
with this Isibel. Isibels hus.husband
was mac Leaspa 'ic a mhinisteir.
He was long in riocrioghachd nan daoine buibuidhe
& the datdaughter of RiRigh nan daondaoine buibuidhe
fell in love with him & exexhorted him to marry
her. She made him a deise of itean
ian – dhan na chuile dath bha
eir ialialaith nan speur & an deise
eleeile do shiodashioda agus uisgair eir
AonBut he ran from her & came
home & marmarried his friend Isebel.

Flora & the Prince left Buail
Unacleit at Minngeary Milton
& crossed to Lochaoineart frfrom
which they sailed.

Don.Donald saw her brobrother Angus who was
a thorough soldier (Poor Donald! He went
away one day to cut rushes & was found dead
aged .

div.title: LaoiLaoidh AlastAlastair Dhuinn
div.p:
From ArchArchibald Currie AirdnamonAirdnamonadh IocarIochdar
28 OctOctober 1872. AlastAlastair Donn was dead
for 24 hours & rose on the eirlig sung
this & then lay down dead as before.
Currie heard this when he was 1½
yrsyears old now 46 yrs.years. AlastAlastair Donn
in Boisdale SSouth Uist (a DonnullachDomhnullach)
now 500 yrs.years ago.

div.title: Cu Du Mhic a Bhi
div.p: From the same.

Bha ciobair do Chlann a Bhi
aig Loch Ollabhat aig Mac ic Ail.Ailein.
Bha e post s cha rorobh sliocsliochd eir. Bha
caileag bheag do sheantshearbhanta aige. Mh
Bha bain.baintighearna ann am BBaile mhanaich a
fithe aodach dha mhnai. Bha
uacaruachdar (inneadh) ga didith & chuir i fios
thun bean a chiob.chiobair gun cuir i
an sgian sin air aod.aodach mar cuir
i thuice inninneadh. O gu de ni mi ors
bean a chiobchiobair s gun e mo chalchall
deantdeante bearb'fhearr gun rorobh mna anmnathan
Dun-bhuilg amga-muigh Is gor.gorach d ordan
A bhlaomastair bhocbhochd gu de chor
ni sidsiod cha dean no ma cha tig
ad g co dhiu. Is gorgorach d orordan thig na
a tig ad. GoirGoirid an deideidh sin chu
chuileas stablaig (trustair mar
each) a chuile te riariamh g iarriarraidh thun
an aurais 's gun sniath ise a
rinnroinn fhefhein dhan innseadh. Leag
a bhean na builg far nan ta
staingean crochaicrochaidh & thug i dh
i dhalbhdhfhalbh ad. ChungChunnaig a bhean gun
rinn i gnothgnothach ceanceana – s cha rorobh
fios ceamciamar a chumchumadh i obair riuriutha
ChaiChaidh fear an taitaigh far an rorobh nan sean
duin. Thuirt an seann duine
falbh & buain fhefhein & a chailg
lan da aprain do channach
an t sleibhe & fiach an cuir
uthu riuriutha gu 12o'cl.12o'clock. Rinn e so
eir a thuiread s gun brist ad
an snathsnathad cancannach chaird ad
e gus an 7th uairuairean. Bha
na mna sin sirsireadh eir a chiobchiobair
an cu dudughdubh a mharbh – s gun
fheum na chuailiche gun
mhath taotaobh an teine. Bha e bothar
(No! no!) ChaiChaidh e sin far an rorobh an
sean duine ristrithist. Till & eubh san
dorust Dun bhuilg na theine &
& leig an cu dughdubh annta. M
ār us inneadh Dun bhuilg a
chuile te riariamh a tilg uaipe a h-
uigheann chal & shin i as Leig
e 'cu dudughdubh as an deigh. Thill
e an la n na mhairmhaireach an cu 'san
gru'angruthan agus an fhionndach
eir a chur aige aig bial
garraigarraidh aig taotaobh Loch Ollabhat.

Other version a tuath at B.Baile vanvanich & his 3
maidein went to a buaile at Buaile
na h aon oicheoidhche. Mac Phi left for
home near dusk. One girl went out
for the calves & in coming home
she saw 2 men coming to the airiairidh.
She looked in on the fairleus & saw
the 2 men a deothol fuil nan da
nieannighean. She ran off aftafter Mac Phi.
They barred the door ere the fuasfuaths camcame

div.p:
FoineachunFoinneachan dudubha old womwoman
at Bornish had warts. She set
to to get 9 straws with 9 uilt on
each sop & 81 for each wart.
Then to dig a pit & put 81 of these
in each for each wart. They were
to be left in the pits till they crionacrionadh
& the warts were gone.

From old Angus Currie bocanbochdan IocairIochdar
29 OctOctober 1872

div.p:
Clanvuirich Staoligeary
were there 360 years. The 17th glun lost it by
throthrough quirks. The last was Niall
mac Lachlain ioc Neill ioc
DhonilDhomhnaill. An fhior lapaichead
thug orra leigeil seachad. All the 13th
glun had the whole of Dremisdale
& the 14th glun & all after had only 4 peighinpeighinn
of Dremisdale & the whole of StaoligStailigeary.
Twas at Garbhath Staoligeary Mac
Vuirich met the biast. he was going home
to Dremisdale frfrom StaoligStailigeary. Cha
teid uthu seachseachad a seo – cait bheil do ghur.ghuraclach
De sin duit a chreatchreatair shuarshuaraich
Thug e ionsionnsaidh s rug e eir a chuilin
aice. Bi seo agam. Lean i e thun
an taitaigh e. Cuir a mach mo bhur
aicleach. An ta cha chuir. Dean
bathach & ciailceangail gun mheang gun
mhearacmhearachd gun marbhithmharbhith. ThoisThoisich
Bior sgrath us sgolapa eir taotaobh
taitaigh tuatuaigh mhioc Coiseim
gach fiodh sa choill ach
fioghagach (fiodh beanbeannaichte) chan
fhaifhaigh mi mar a chuir mi.
Bior sgrath sgolapa &
Twas finishfinished ere dawn. Dean
clachan Lainginish gun
lub gun cham o ghrundghrunnd gu
barr gun mor bhi. She left
& she was not to touch a ban
no dearg an taotaobh is taitaigh na loiniloinidh.
She reachreached Sgor Huissinish & foudfound
there a crew of fishfishermen a bruich bhonnacbhonnach.
She baked her own bonbonnach & elbowed
the men here & there but she got neanear
the fire. As mo raadrathad sibh s leig
liom mo gheirman beag a bhruich.
Bu duile liom am fear beag
claon ruaruadh choinchoinnich mi eir Garbh
aath Staol.Stailigeary na sibh uile gu leir.
GhaGhabh i sios far an rorobh dara le na
an t-eathar eir sa dara leth
eir bhog. Bhuail i 'n leth bha
eir bhog & bhrist i i 's cha do bhris
i dhala bha eir tir. GhaGhabh i mach
choinchoinnich ei barc & thuirt i.

div.p:
Borve Castle was built by Fiosgo Fiosgo
Burc, (an Irish lady) Had much
monymoney hersefherself & datdaughter. She was a widow.

HowmorHowmore, One of the tuatuath at Howmore
had to faire na cuidh which was where
the cladh at Hough. He wishwished to go fishfishing
to Loch sgiopart so CatrinaCatriona nieannighean
DonilDhomhnaill Ghuirm vol.volunteered During night
she saw all the graves open Then she saw
all the tenants coming & going into their
graves. She saw then a wom.woman coming NienNighean
DDhomhnaill Ghuirm ran & plplaced her cuigeal
across the grave Tog do bhata
said the – thoir do mhaid as a sdsiod
Bheil truas agad mu na bha
do dh fhairge ghlas dodol tharam
fad na h-oicheh-oidhche. Leig i orr mo char
fhefhein riuriutha sa liudliuthad mumuir gorm
a chadchaidh tharam S mise Mor niannighean
RiRigh LochlanLochlain Thainig mi fhefhein
s mo 3 bhrabhraithrean a LLochlann & bhrist an long
eir an so sinn eir ceann Alba
& bhathadh sin – Micheal Aulaidh
& Peadeir (who was fodfound on shore
at Kil PheadPheadair with a gold locket round
his neck – hence name of KillKill Pheadair) leig
a sios mi s gheogheobh uthu nas ma dhuit
shiol ann truig agams ri taotaobh
na sgeire aig bun na faolach
& tha stamh a fas no druim
faifaigh cuid.cuideachd & thoir a i 's gheogheobh uthu nas
fheaird uthu. Thog N.Nighean D.Dhomhnaill G.Ghuirm a cuigeal
s leig i sios i dhan lic i s thug an t or san aairgiod
san inndas dha na buic. The
cuicuidh was openopened but none in came
out

up to Lochseille for a deerhound
Dog 3½ ftfeet high & 1½ deep in chest. Black
Bor Bran. He broke in to Airigh
Cuinn mate uncle DonDonald Mac Uan
got a stirk there then & ea ate it almost
the whole stirk every morngmorning. He chased
a stag came up bit it AuinAbhuinn Dheid
ain struck it in the hind leg with 30 OctOctober 187

Donnacha MacCuilcein
NinNighean DonilDomhnaill ioc Cathain (Nic

MacCuilcein was the first to build,
the first mill in Uist. He dammed,
up the water at Howmore & a great
flood came & covered all the ground.

div.p:
The "cailleach" was sent frfrom a neighneighbour
who finishfinished cutgcutting his corn to his unfinishunfinished
neighneighbour. This was considconsidered a great disgrace
& has been the cause of many quarrels.
A man went frfrom Bornish on horse
back with the cailleach & left it Milton.
A man started aftafter him caught
him in Ro-glasRoe-glas brotbrought him back
shaved his whiskers & head & sent
him home with bearradh eoin
us amadain.

Dul an Droma in Gearry
Geanacha sent the CaillchCailleach
to Patra Nicolson Cnoc na
moine BenBenbecula The messgrmessenger
was cautcaught striptstripped naked & so sent
home. A tacksman would
rather find his best cow dead
than the cailcailleach in his iomaire buain
Two neighneighbours at IocarIochdar had about
equal buana to do at night. One
got up at midnight so as to finish
before his neighneighbour. Just when near
his buain he met his neighneighbour retgreturning
home after finishing & building a
cairn at the end of his neighneighbour's
rig wherein he stuck the cailcailleach.
The cailcailleach is the last cut sheaf
of corn decorated up with cuiseagan
buatharlain & tied with rags &c

Tha gach buaibuaidh ag-eiriag-eiridh leibh
Gur tir each us gig a falafalbh leis
Sa ghille ga dhraivdhraibheadh dhuidhuibh
Gun na thagh e ceilceile banail
Iose-Beallag beanbeannachadh na sisith
Miar a fhlur aig an t-sioda
Chuir an grain eir gu grinn
S gile i nonnan cancanach fo h-earradh
No an sneacasneachd ga chur sna glinglinn
Nar thlacartlachdmhar, 's mor naire
Am bial bo'eachboidheach sni m baranbanrighinn binn
GruaiGruaidh tha na dhearg is glan dearse
Falt donn fainfainneach gu chur an cir
Gur h-ise mairmathair nam braireanbrathairean
Cho aluinaluinn san th-ann s aman tir
Se siod Nil & gor
Giullain bho eachbhoidheach dh fas gun mheang
'S leig na thainig dha lai'eanlathaichean
Gun h-al.h-alainn an leddileadaidh i
Gun inntinnte fhastfhathast ach leanart
Ga h-alth-altram aig Peiggi ghrieve
Fhuair i urram anns gach doidoigh
MhaighMhaighdinn sheombar thainig leibh.
Rial.Riaghladh fion eir bord dhaoin uaisluaisle

A cumail suas dhuibh gach
gach ni
AoghaiAghaidh gach sonsonais s gach solais
Ho hir ir ir ho ro ho ho hir ir ir iui
Hiu na hi ri ho ro ho é hoilird horohavi

div.title: MacMuc Dhearg
div.p:
Iain Macinnes Staoligeary
S.South Uist 29 JanJanuary 1875
Friday in his own house aged 70.

Bha bhean fhein aig MacIllMhoire
Howgearry N.North Uist muigh buain
Thug i lealeithe a leanaleanabh mic muigh s chuir
i ri taitaigh adaig e – leanaleanabh diolandionlain
Bha a leanaleanabh caoincaoineadh s chaichaidh i mach
s thug i cioch dha. Bha e caoinecaoineadh
fhastfhathast – s gun a dhuan a bhial
ach muc dhearg muc dhearg
Thug i dhachdhachaidh e s chuir i phreis
eir an teine s rinn i brochbrochan dha
s chuir Dh iarr MacIllMhoire
liopain chuir eir a phreis. Thug
adh siod dha – s cha rorobh dhuan
a bhialbheul ach muc dhearg muc
dhearg. Chuir a phreis a ristrithist eir
an teine s dh iarr MacMacIllMhoire ocrann
(½ peck) chuir eir a phreis. Thugadh
siod dha s cha rorobh dhuan a bhialbheul
ach muc dhearg &c. SgriSgriobh Mac
Ille Mhoire lione loine dhi s dh iarr
orra tinntighinn gu MacMhuirich
Mor StaoiligStaoiligeary (He was the first who
came to StaoligStaoiligeary of the race) Thainig
i s choinchoinnich i mach e shin i a
loine dha. Thug a stigh e. Dh iarr
eir a bhan straisear teanteann a stigh
ri an teine s iad a chuir eir teine
s biabiadh dhi. RinRinneadh seo Dh iarDh iarr e sin
poit mhor a chitsin chuir eir NarNuair
bha i eirson mine a chur orra
dh iarr e s ocran mhine chur
orra. Bha ie sior auracamhairc eir an
leanaleanabh s gun a dhuan a bialbeul an
leanleanabh ach muc dhearg. NuarNuair
bha am biabiadh sin eirson a chosg
chuir a sios an t seomar e fhefhein
sa mhair? Cha rorobh greim bha
sa phoit s cha rorobh duan a bhialbheul
ach muc dhearg &c. ChaiChaidh a sin
MacMhuirMacMhuirich Mor a sios sa chlogadchlogaid
cruach sa luireach mhailleach
eir sa chlaiclaidheamh mor na dhorn Chuir
e chuile duinduine mach as an rum
ach e fhein san leanaleanabh. Thuirt
a sin an leanaleanabh Muc dhearg &c
S thuirt Mac MMacMhuirich Muc dhearg Muc dh
dhearg ors an Muc dhearg os MacMacMhuirich
Thuirt a sin McMacMhuirich sa togail a chlaichlaidheamh
A mhuc dhearg sa mhuc dhearg
sa mhuc le-cheanachleth-cheannach le dhearg
a mhuc a mhara mac a luin
sa thug e eir a mhuic gu dhun
S leig a dhiouldhiabhail bi fagail mo
thaigh. LeanaLeanabh a sin an leanaleanabh
a mach eir an lin'ein. ThalaThalla
nis dhachdhachaidh ors MMacMhuirich ris a mhnaoi
agus gheogheobh uthu do leanaleanabh fhein aig
an taitaigh gu min clu'ar a stia ort
SanSann a nairnuair theid uthu mach a bhuan
thoirt leat eileageibhleag ghuail aln luib
aod.aodaich s mus theid uthu mach eir
oicheoidhche thoirt leat an ealeibhleag ghuail
s nach reachrachadh air oicheoidhche sidsiod
lai gun an ealeibhleag ghuail an luib
aod.aodaich do leinibh s na fuagfuasgail uait
ea idir e gun seo. Hence
their practice still to take eileageilbhleag
ghuail an luib aodaodaich leine. The
ealeibhleag is still left by the side of the child
when left at side of stook at sheargshearing
time)

Bhean bhan 'n Caolas Liuarsey.
agus bha i bocbochd ris a bhas s thuirt i ri Mac
fuifuirich ga. cairis gun duinduine ach e fhefhein
s gu faigh e chuile sin saoltsaoghalta bha
aice – gun bi leis fhein e. Bhas-Bhasaich
seo s dia bha eagal eir a ghille
gad a gheall i fuirfuireach a stigh ga
caris. Bha e seo a spaideireacspaideireachd
eir ais san aghartadhart mun dordorus
Thainig a seo saithachsoitheach gu acair
sa Chaolas. Tha mi faifaicinn fear a siod
ors an sgiobair s cha chreid mi
nach eil dragh eir – reach eir
tri illeangillean s facfaic gu dude e dhragh
Thug na gilgillean gu bord an gille. De
tha cuir dragh ort illille mhath
ors an sgsgiobair Tha mo mhaairmhathair
marbmarbh eir eislig s gheall
mi gun duinduine thoirt gu caris
ach mi fhefhein. An taitaigh bhrobhronach na gheangheanach
ri sin sir uthu e ach mar geal chun
na gil cocomhla riut. Ach bheil biobal
agad a Tha. am bheil sgrisgriobhadh agad.
Chan eil ach leuleugh mi an biobal.
Bheir mis dhuit biobbiobal & coilleach
Seo mar thach.thachair Thug e dha 3 choilchoillich
greis & coinealcoinneal cheire. CuirCuiridh tu na
na coilcoillich greis sin eir a bhord sa choilchoineal
cheire na meanmeadhon san biobal
aig ceann a chuip – s bi bti tu
fhein a leughaleughadh a bhiobail eile
sadhadh mi na mthean gum
faic no dhan chuir ri cheicheile
tog u do cheann. Seo bh ma bha
mu mheanmheadhon oichoidhche thainig am
fuasfuathas nach cuala ri leidleithid s chuir
e cricrith eir an taitaigh Bheil uthu tinntighinn a
mach a chumail do ghealghealladh rium
ors am fuasfuathas. Chri na tha an taotaobh
shios dhan da ghluin disedeise DheirDheirich
e sin a ristrithist gus ghluais na bha
nan taotaobh shios an da chich air an
n turas Bheil uthu tinntighinn mach a chumchumail
do ghealghealladh rium 3 turas – DemarDiamar
is S urraurrainn mise dhol mach sam biob
al aig mo cheann ach thig usathusa
stigh gun iarriarraidh s thoir leat mi
DemarDiamar thig mise staistaigh s mar
na circ eir an spar.spardan san
coilcoileach a sior ghairm. Ghairm an
coilcoileach s chuir na 3 choilchoilean ghreis as
Las an gil ris a chilchoinneal cheir -
(3 times) Dh fhalbh e n uair sin &
thainig e n 3 turas am fuasfuthas na
fhuabhsaich na bha ie riariamh. Ghairm
Leis a chrichrith an taitaigh san talatalamh
as chaichaidh na coilcoinneal gceir as. Las
an gillgille ard ris a choinealchoinneal cheir
3 uair Bheil uthu tinntighinn mach chumchumail
na coincoinnealan rium mar a ghealgheall uthu CiaCiamar
thig mi sam biobbiobal aig rud cheann.
Ach thig usthus a stigh Chan urra
mismise dol is taitaigh us mar na circ
air an spar.spardan Ghearr an corp
leum far na h-eilig gu ai
mach. Ghearr an coilcoileach leum eadeadar
an corp san dorust s ghairm
e dh falbh am fuasfuathas bha muigh
an uair sin – thainig an lalatha
Thainig a sin sgiobsgiobair an tsaith
aichsoitheach agus dh-fhaidirdh'fhidir e rorobh duinduine
beo ann. Tha mismise beo ach se
sin fhein uile e ors an gille.
Cha n ionaiongnadh liom sin – nam bibitheadh tu faicfaicinn
na bha mismise faicfaicinn ors an sgiobsgiobair. DhinDh innis
a sin an gillgille dhan chuile sinsian mar
dh eirdh eirich dha sa bhruithbhruithinn bha aca
s mar bha an solust dol as s an
gniamh rinn an coilcoileach. Thainig a
ma nuair sin crew an t soithsoitheach
s thiolaicthiodhlaic 'ad cul an taitaigh i – thuirt
ad nach cuir ad do chladdhchladh idir i
Thug an sgiobsgiobair leis an gille gu bord.
Dh fhuirDh fhuirich ad nan cariscairis an oidheoidhche sin.
ChunChunnaic ad a sin mu mheanmheadhon oicheoidhche
am meall teine sin a tintighinnas an airde tuatuath sa bualbualadh
an ceann an taitaigh. Sa mhaduinn
bha nan taitaigh na smal gun chlach
air cloich dhi – Chan fhuirfhuiricheadh an
gille san duaichduthaich idir leis an
sgrath & leis an fhuasfhuamhas a ghaghabh e.

div.title: A Bhuileaistach
div.p:
Bha MacMuirich tintighinn as a bheinbheinn lalatha &
stoirm do ghaoighaoith D.Dheas us uisge ann
Sann an Eilein a churric thachair
eiseinisean colas duinduine eir an cois creaigecreige
(Eilean na Built.Buileaistach deas eir an seo.)
Thog e leis an luib a bhreacbhreacain dhachdhachaidh e.
An ceanceann treis thainig an ulai thruisulla-thruis
hurmaich harmich s dh iarr i
h isein rusligruislig a chuir a mach
thuice no gur h e clach b isle bha
san taitaigh aige clach a b airde bhiodh
ann. ChaiChaidh easan na chlogchlogaid cruacruaidh
s na luirluireach sa chlaichlaidheamh na dhorn Cha
chuir ors easeasan tha mismise fo m chuid
arm. san lalatha s treas bha uthu riariamh
fhuaidh mi ris an lar uthu. Ach
dean clachan domhs eir am
faifaigh mi mo chas tiriomtioram a chuile
lalatha sa bhlianabhliadhna gu ruig a Laingi
nis s gheogheobh uthu do chuilchuilean eir a chu
nantchumhnant nuair a thig uthu. Dh fhalaDh fhalbh i.
Chuir i na clachain mora
mora sin – te sid s te seo eir
am faigh fear le sinteag a null
tior.tioram Thainig i seo Tha sidsiod ulamhullamh ors ise mach mo
chuilchuilean rusligruislig dhomh neo se a
chlach &c. Cha chuir a bhiast.
Tha mismise fom chulaichulaidh chruachruaidh
cha s mo chlaichlaidheamh mor am dhorn
s an lalatha b fhearr bha uthu ririamh dhiandheanainn
briste friaite dhiot ris an lar
Ach gheogheobh uthu air chuntchumhnant eir
Dean taitaigh do Phal crubach
Mac Coisin ann an Geirnish
Dh falaDh fhalbh i sin sop sggolpsgolp s sgrahsgrath
air taotaobh taitaigh Mhic Coisin – Chan
fhaifhaigh mi mar mar a chuncaschunnacas
mi – gach fiodh sa choillchoille ach
fiodhagach (sacred wood – What kind)
Bha nan taitaigh ulamhullamh s thill i. Mach mo
isein rusligruislig dhomh ors ise Ma thig
uthu staigh eir a sin ni fuai mise ris
an lar n an lalatha b fhearr bha uthu riariamh
(Smiorlin best lint finest Asgaist craisen
kind) after putgputting it throthrough the cloth
Bha eagal air Neil Niall Mor gun
tig a bhiast na bheatha s thuirt e gheogheobh
eir chunantchumhnant e – DianDean crann
gatha dhan t-shimid. M' aile us
m eimceist crann gath dhian an
t shimidt simid rud nach b urrab urrainn mi dhiandhianamhdheanamh
Dhirich i sin thun an taitaighs ruig i
eir a chor-thulachain(1) Rough Sketch of cross beam The centre
stick in end of house which supports
the end ceal(1) Thug an taitaigh ran as
Stad slad a bhiast & gheogheobh uthu t eisenisean
air chuntchumhnant. De na cuntcumhnant bhios
a sin ors ise. Falbh as an duaichduthaich
far nach faic mi fhein no
duine s duine dhomh gu brachbrath
uthu mi ort rot romhat Cail
uthu g ordg ordachadh dhomh dhol ors ise
Tha mi coma cantca an teid uthu ged
do reachrachadh tu gu ruige Beinn
h-eadaruin – S fad sin eir falbh
s fhearr dhol ann no m eiseanisean
a chaill. Shin e sin a mach dhi
an t isent eisean. Rug i sin eir an isenisean
s thoisthoisich i ri gailgabhail an talaitalaidh 's chuir
air a gualaingualainn e.

lg.l: S fhada bhuam fhin bonn BeanBeinn headar.h-eadaruin
S fhada bhuam, bhuam BealBealach a Mhorghain
repeat
repeat gun teagateagamh BealBealach a Mhorgh.Mhorgahin
S o bhonn gu bonn bonn BeinBeinn headrh-eadaruin
S o bhonn BealBealach a MhorMhorghain
O bhonn gu bonn bhonn B-Beinn h-eadaruin
S fhada gun teagateagamh uambhuam BealBealach a Mhorghain
Cul nam bealbealaichean 's bonn nam bad
Cul nam BealBealaichean a MhorghMhorghain
Cul nam BealBealaichean 's bonn nam bad
S fhada gun teagateagamh uambhuam BealBealach a MhorghMhorghain

div.p:
Dh fhalaDh fhalbh i mar sin. ChaiChaidh as am
fianais. Rainig i sin an Ceann
tuatuath. Co bha sin ach Macleoid na h Ear
adh a togail creiche. Bha Macleoid
fhein sa bhiorlinbhiorlinn s na daoine aigaige
eir tir ann an tent Lochmaddy Thog ise cul dha'n
t seol s chuir i ceann is taigh
s drein orra s fiaclain fada
cinn lealeth troitroighmach ro carabad.
Bha na daoine toistoiseachadh ri ichith rosladh
daimh. Leum ad a mach a
muin eir mhuin bronnaich
eir tharruich s mharamharbhadh S bhath.bhathadh
pairstpairt dhiudhiubh mun d fhuair
ad a bhiorlinbhiorlinn thoirt a mach.
Beagadh ort oribh a thrustair
- bu duile liom an aon fhear
claon ruaruadh thachair orm eir
Gara ath Garbhag Staolagearry
na sgioba na biorlinbiorlinn uile
ShuiShuidh i sios i fhein sa h isenisean
s ghaghabh i am biabiadh dh roslair dh fagdh fhag
na daoine. Sin a chiad bhiabhiadh ghaghabh
i o na chaill i n t isein.

Built by RaolRaghnall mac Ailein. He
lived at Dremisdale & his son
onin MorirMorair. A hard spring came
& the son came ashore at Loch
sgiopart for provender. I cant
give you any said the father – it's
scarce with myself - I have only 3
stacks. At night the son went
out & began taking down a stack
The gre eirgreighear came in & wakened
his master & told him his son was on
the top of the stack taking it away. Up
Rose Clanranald in his night-shirt with
his bow in hand. He threw & knocked down
his son & the sheaf together. His son left
a son in MorirMorair & Clan fearing that his
own grandson might come & kill
him built Dun-RailDun-Raghnaill. The ath &
iodhlan are on "Eilean nan tailear".

div.title: Ron
div.p:
TuanachTuathanach a bhann s bhatair g ichith an
aran eir san atha Cha rorobh fhios aig
eir an t saolt saoghal codaciod a bha g ichith an arinarain
s chaichaidh eir iocariochdar an aran na h ah-atha fon
aran s thug e leis lachran mor
thainig a sin ron beag us ron mor
is taitaigh s thoisthoisich ad eir ichith an arain
Thug eas.easan tiontionndadh eir fhein gus buile
thoirt dhaibh. Tha fracas a seo Transcribed into
Book No I Book
p. 189
A.Alexander A.Archibald C.Carmichael
Creagorry
7 OctOctober 1875
ors an ron beag. Thoir eis an airaire
eir na h agad chan eil ann ach
fracas luchag. Bha ad a sin
g ichith. Tha fracas a seo a ors
an ron beag. Chan eil no fracas
thoir us nairan aire eir na thagad
chan eil ann ach fracas luchag
&c. Tha fracas a seo gun teagamh
Thug an duine stracsrac dhan lachran
dhan ron mhor s bhuail e eadeadar
an da shuil e s bhios theich
am fear beag a mach air feadan
na h-atha sa am fear mor assa
ghlugadaich as a dhioidheidh. Seo a nis
ors am fear beag tha do cheann maid
lialiath air a bhrist fiach a nis an
fracas luchag e -

Thainig fear a Taisgeir s chaichaidh
e eir saothsoitheach a null thar chuan gu
eile.eilean fiadhaich ChaiChaidh e gu taotaobh shiar
mor lialiath a sin CodCiod as a thainig uthu
ThaingThainig as a Cheann a tuatuath Co s
daoindaoine dhut a sin Mac iogain
Iog.Iogain gad a thu mi am bith dhut
Im us cais us feòil.

Eir mo lamh IogIogain 's eir a dha
lamh s gar saorach IogIogain gun
a chuir uthu nan gath am spoig &c
Bhruich fiodhainfeadhainn roin s thilg
ad a mach na cre'uncreamhun nan torr
eir an t sitig. Spog Fionaghala
spog spaidrich spog mo
chul chaoimh chaid spog mo
rinn fada finghealla s i cuir
ninnighean fada fuingheala s i cuir nan cnacnamhun. Bha fear eile
annsann mharamharbh e ron s bha e sior
chairnechairneadh na saille b eir – nach b
fhiach e. AmAn deigh dol an lailaighe chunchunnaic
ad a sin duradh mor san uisguisge
's thuirt an guth

lg.l:
och nan och
cha mhis an ron
Och nan chan mhis an ron
Ach an curraicurraidh mor gu fior
Dhou'llDhomhnuill ic AlastAlastair shaoir
Ga bu diumbach uthu dha m shaill
Dh fhag uthu mo chraunchramhun sa lom
S bi do chlann san irionn shios

div.title: Caileach Ghlinn Dorcha
div.p:
Bha fear sa bheinn sa Ghleann dorcha
chrom e ann. ChunChunnaic e boirboireannach dol
seach.seachad s cota gorm us bidagunbeadagun geala
orroirre s currach gaileachgaidhealach mu ceann.
Chuir e urreacurrachd orra nach b ann
saoltsaoghalta bha i. Co dha bhuineas tu bhean
Is mis cailcailleach a Ghlin.Ghlinne Dorcha
A chailchaillich bheurra bheag an fhas.fhasaich innsinnis
dhomhs de d aois? NuirNuair bha an
fhairge ghlas na coillcoille sann
bha mis nam ninnighean. BhuaininBhuaininn
mo chrioslachan chno eadar
dha BhorarnisBhoranais bhuainbhuaininn mo 9 imimirean
lin eadar an an lagan min Choradan
Duileasg Leac o Le agir cneamh
Sgōir uisge Loch a chean dóin iasg
an Ionaire mhoir sin mo
ratha beatha sa fhada sa bhios mi
beo s i falbh na ruith s cha rorobh an t'ath
shealshealladh aige dhi. (Nuts are found
at Boirnish & tree roots. also nuts found
at Clachan Ceann an Toirbeart under
18 feet moss, on the gravel. John Mac
Phadruig saw a sithein open & light in it
at Geary nan curran Sithein Cui nan
Stuidh. Two others I myself would give an
oth oath upon this. Horses ploughplouging there
ran away with the plough frfrom the place.
This at dusk.

div.title: Ceudach Nan {Collachain {doors Oir
div.p:
Bha Fionn & a mhor shluashluagh san t sealg
eir a cleith orra. Dh falbhDh fhalbh e fhein agus
a mhor shluashluagh gu Beinn-eadoBeinn-eadorro agus
fhuair ad an t shleag mhor fhialach
ionach nach d fhuair ad riariamh a leidleithid
ChruinChruinneachadh ad a sin an t sealg gu aona
chrocchnoc. BhuailBhuaileadh aid a sin sealg a chuilchuile
fir & rinn ad eir a cheile gus a toirsttoirt
dachdachaidh. Se bun a bh'ann bha ealealach fhefhein
trom eir a chuile fear bu cheacharra
leoleotha sgath fhagail s bu nar leoleotha gun
reachrachadh ad a dhidhith no gun toi tuit
ad an toll ga tartarraing dachdachaidh. Fhad sa
bha ad a dhidhith sl seilg no sithinsithinn. Bha
ad eadar adha chomhairle nan seasseasamh
s gun fhios aca de dhiandhianamh ad. ChunChunnaic
ad fras a sileadh a cri na h-airde
an iar s chrom ad taotaobh tuim gus
an fhras a leigleigeil dhiudhiubh. Ath deir
chunchunnaic ad gille ghlas. BheanBheannaich e do
dh Fhionn s bheanbheannaich Fionn da s
dh-fhaindh-fhaighneachd e co aan duinduine a no cait
bha roimhe ruighinn CCaoilte gu'n cead
a righ Eirinn bha mhiann orm sibh
fhein a ruith fiach am faigh cos
nadh gheogheobh uthu sin coscosnadh agamsa
Ach sann a reir s mar bheir uthu dhac
aidh dhan t sealg bhios do thurasdal
Ro cheart ors an gille glas cearn
eallach. Thug ad a sin bodach far a duill
gad gus eal.eallach dhianadhianamh dha. Ne sid on
eallach sa – cha b uileir dhomhs uiruiread
eile. TapaTapadh leat ille ghlais – chi sinn
de ni uthu eir a sin fhefhein siu'adsiuthad mata
Cuiridh an cois s fhearr th agabhagaibh
eir falbh cocomhla riumsa dh ion.dh ionnsaidh an talla
na FinneFeinne. Chuir ad Caoilte air falafalbh
on s e bu luailuaidh cas gus an talla ion-ionnsaidh
s bha ealealach fhein air CaoiltCaoilte. Bha an gille
Ga teannadh o ChChaoilte – Cha b' fhada
gus an rorobh thuar eir a Ghille ghlas gun
cailcailleadh e sealsealladh air C-Caoilte – Thilg a seo CaoltCaoilte
an ealeallach thar a dhroma gur he eir
GhGhille Glas. Se bun a bh'ann a chuile sloc
dhiandhianamhan G.Gille Glas nan reachrachadh CCaoilte ann rechrachadh
e dhidhith – le cudrom na h-ealh-eallaich s le
luas a chas. Se bh ann chaill CCaoilte sealsealladh
eir a GhGhille Ghlas – Bha seo na Fianntaich
a tinntighinn sa chuile fear ri na fhallas
gu greasgreasad dhachdhachaidh aig mar bha

talanttalamh fhastfhathast. Cha tig an aon

S ol S math tha fios am ceann

ach dileas deodeagh mhaistirmhaighstir dhuit

3 oichoidhche ach nach dian tu oichoidhche

Fiach tu fo ceann an uair

uthu. Thachair mar seo. Theich
an t Suil muimhoidearra ris. Seadh osors

Rinn ors an C-Ceudach thugainn a nis
s gum bi rud a falafalbh chun na
pairce. Rainig ad a seo dorust
na pairce. Thug e na h-uichh-iuchichean dha'n

s chaichaidh ad is taigh. ThachThachair aan sin tobar

ors C-Ceudach Tha dh' aon bhuaibhuaidh eir gad

uthu. An ta theid usthusa ann ors C-Ceudach
An ta cha b e mo chomhairlchomhairle
dhuit. ComhComhairle ann no as theid
uthu ann. FalaiFalbhaidh & stopaistopaidh sios an
coin a chinn ann as tobar e.
Bha e na fhleasgfhleasgach min sgiamh

sin air a thob.thobar riu.riutha gu de brianbriatharan
an tobtobar seo. Seo tobtobar gad bhidbhiodh

sa. Thug ad leolethoa 2 bhotal. Sheas

dh fhag ad na iuchiuchraichean san ghlais
Bha ad aan sin gailgabhail air n aghaghaidh

FFhinn eir og phosphosadh – s gun duil

div.p:
Bha lananlannan a bhata troirt glig-
eadaichgliogadaich eir a h-urlar aig fiodh
each a na fairge. Oan tha bhualbhualadh
air son a luadach. NanNann a bhalbhalaich.
a giarg iarraidh orm an 3 iartiarratas orm iar eir
mo Chrui.Chruithear san aon lalatha. Thainig
iad eir tir san t Acairseid fhal-
s chaichaidh na miremirean fon cas.

Se mac bantraichbanntraich bha Mac
MhuirMacMhuirich s chr an Eirinn. ChungChunnaig e lais
ligleig s dh iarr an guth eir eirieiridh gun rorobh
taitaigh gu bhibhith na lasair ma cheann
Dh eirDh eirich e s theich e mach. Leig e
cheann eir tom s thuit e na chadchadal
s thainig guth ga ion.ionnsaidh dh iarr e eir
s e thar thinthighinn a dh-Uistdh-Uibhist gu bhibhith
na aosdana s na fhear uirsgeul
Ciamar bhios mise sin o gun
ghuth sgoil agam. Fiach usathusa
fod cheann s bi sgoil gu leoir
agad. Dhuisg e sin s dh fhiach
e fo cheann s fhuair ann a sin
e leabhar dearg Mhic Mhur.Mhic Mhuirich
Leugh a e an leorleabhar mar gun
lan sgoil e. Cha rorobh fine bha
nan Alba non ErinEireann nach rorobh san
LearLeabhar dhearg. Thainig e sin
gu ruig UistUibhist s fhuair e StaolStadhlaigearraidh
& 4 peinpeighinn DhrDhreimeasdail, 5 peinpeighinn Dr
in all – worth more £100 – i.e. £80
the 4 penpennies StaolStaoligearry worth £80 2 l
